div.head: THE EGYPTIAN GAZETTE
No. 7,412] ALEXANDRIA, Tuesday, FEBRUARY 6, 1906. [EIGHT PAGES P.T. 1.
The Eastern Telegraph Company, Limited.
div.p:
This Company's system of submarine telegraph
cables is the most direct and quickest means of
communication from Egypt to Europe, North and
South America, East, South and West Africa,
India, Australia, New Zealand, China and Japan.

To secure quick transmission, telegrams should
be marked Via Eastern.

For latest average time to London, see daily
bulletin in this paper.

STATIONS IN EGYPT: Alexandria, Cairo,
Suez, Port-Tewfik, Port-Saïd, Suakin. Head
Office. London.

div.head: Peninsular and Oriental S. N. Company.
div.p: Berths can be definitely engaged beforehand. Plans can be seen at the Office of the Company's Agents.

The through Steamers for Marseilles, Gibraltar, Plymouth and London are intended to leave Port said after the arrival of the 11 a.m. train from Cairo, Every Monday. A steam tender will meet the train to convey passengers to the ship.
The Brindiel Express Steamer leaves Port Said directly the Indian Mails arrive. Passengers can go on board the evening before.
The express steamer usually reaches Brindisi on Wednesday afternoon, the special train starting at 8 p.m. and arriving in London at the very convenient hour of 4.56 p.m. on Friday.
The combined sea and special train fare os 22.9.11 Port said to london via Brindisi or via Marseilles.
Passengers having paid full fare in one direction are allowed an abatement of 25 per cent. on returning within 12 months.
In addition to the above regular weekly service there are sailings about twice a fortnight of 5,000 to 7,000 tons steamers to London calling Malta or Marseilles.
TO THE EAST

The Mail Steamers leave Suez for Aden and Bombay every Wednesday, and for Australia and China every altenate Wednesday. A steamer leaves for Calcutta, fortnightly, and another for Japan. Passengers can embark at Port Said.

div.head: KHEDIVIAL MAIL LINE.
div.p: Express Steamers leave Alexandria every Wednesday at 4 p.m. for PIRAEUS, SMYRNA, MITYLENE, and CONSTANTINOPLE, in connection with Orient Express train-de-luxe for Vienna, Paris, and London.

Fast steamers leave Alexandria every Saturday at 4 p.m., and Port Said every Sunday at 6 p.m., for JAFFA (for Jerusalem), CAIFFA (for Nazareth), BEYROUT (for Damascus), TRIPOLI, ALEXANDRETTA, MESSINA, continuing in alternate weeks to LARNACA and LIMASSOL (Cyprus).

Steamers leave Suez weekly on Wednesday at 6 p.m. for JEDDAH, SUAKIN, MASSOWAH, HODBIDAH, and ADEN ; and in the intervening weeks for PORT SUDAN and SUAKIN direct. Calls will be made at TOR (for Mount Sinai) as required.
N.B.—Deck chairs provided for the use of passengers, excellent cuisine and table wine free.
Steamer plans may be seen and passages booked at the Company's Agencies at Alexandria, Cairo, Port Said, and Suez, or at THOS. COOK & SON or other Tourist Agency.

TUESDAY, FEBRUARY 6, 1906.

div.head: ARMY REFORM
div.p: What Mr. Halane will do at the War Office lies in the womb of the future, but if we are to believe his own utterances we know what he will not do. He has assured us very emphatically that he means to keep Army administration quite outside party politics, and hopes to place its efficiency before all questions of economy and finace. Thee are brave words, rather suggestive of the novice who has never yet benn under the Treasury lash, and we may recall them some day when he has been compelled to prune down his too ambitious estimate to meet the requirements of some cheese-paring Budget. Another promise will be more easily kept. Mr Haldane should have no difficulty in maintain pleasant relations with his military colleagues. the expert memmbers of the Army concil, and will avoid friction cause by differeces of opinon and want of personal sympathy which certainly porevailed often during the late regime. The new secaratary of state has the advantage of an affable and concililiatory manner, and he has begun well by a franl admission of his ignoreance of army affairs and his willingnedd to be guided by those who are better informed. The chief fault in Mr. Arnold-Forster was that he knew everything better than anyone else. He was, moreover tied and bound by the previously-expressed views on some of the most intricate points in a business of the most extreme difficulty. Mr. Haldane tells us he has an open mind and if this attitude is lasting and permits him to accept the best that his predecessors have already given us, there may be some hope of a settlement of matter still in a fluid condition.

We hear much of the provision of a national army as the chief aim to be helf in view by our new War Office administrator, and no one will question its paramount importance. The phrase is mere bombastunless it is analysed and an exact definition arrived at. The commom idea is that defence of Great Britain is the principal raison detre of a national army. Many people discount this on the faith or rather hasty conclusions that invasion is out of the question. We leave this consideration aside, convinced that our real and more pressing needs lie beyond the four seas- needs at the remote extremities of our far-flung frontier line, and no doubt for the moment in abeyance. Yet our army exsits primarily for foreign service, for the current police duties of the Empire and to meet the larger and more desperate emergencies that may some day arise. To prepare for them acequately is the true role of the far-seeing War Minister, and the best, the only effective, means is the constitution of an enormus reserve of stored up strength available for prompt mobilisation in the hour of trial. The auxiliary forces can never be utilised on their present footing, and we know now that the sugguested organization of a home service army will not work on the lines proposed by Mr. Arnold-Forester. The necessary personnel are not forthcoming; the men will not join the newly devised regiments, for some unexplained reason another instance of the caprices of voluntary enlistment. The problem remains to be solved by Mr. Haldane, if indeed, he touches it at all unless it is forced upon him.

He has a full programme and has many urgent needs on his card. The question of recruiting is, as ever, of the first importance, and likely to become accentuated should the party now in power be beguiled into coqueting with Home Rule. It has been pointed out that with an independent Parliament in Dublin the British Army would look in vain for Irish recruits, hitherto so valuable an addition to the forces of the crown. Apart from their soldierly qualities, the loss in numbers would be felt seriously. Mr. Haldane has declared himself, as might have been expected, the determined opponent of any form of conscription. What if it is forced upon him as the direct result of making Irishmen foreigness? Let us hope that the notion is far-fetched and that the evil consequences of Home Rule in this regard may be averted. A more pressing requirement today is to find officers for all branches of the service and more particularly the auxiliary forces, where the dearth constantly increases. Neither the Militia nor the Volunteeers can take their place in the national array until this defect is mended, and the remedy, except by regular payment is not easy to find. The shortage in the regulars has been in a measure dealt with by Mr. Arnold Forster, although hardly on large permanent lines. The late War Minister has to some extent smoothed his successor's path by carrying out the rearmament of the field artillery and the introduction of the new infantry rifle, but his legacy of the great General Staff is a more doubtful asset not readily or easily realisable.

div.head: CUT OUT HER TONGUE - A FANATIC WOMAN'S ATTEMPT TO WORK A MIRACLE
div.p: According to the "Straits Times" a procession of Hindus took place recently in Singapore, the men being under hypnotic influence and with barbs of iron and wood sticking in their flesh. Interest in the procession centred in a woman, known for her great piety. She joined in the procession with a brass pot, containing pure water, which she hoped would turn into milk.

To her disappointment and dismay she found on uncovering the pot at her destination that the water was unchanged. Not to be outdone, she tried to bring about another miracle. Seizing a knife which she carried, she cut off her tongue about an inch from the end and laid it on a leaf in front of her. With blood dripping from her mouth, she knelt before this bit of tongue, praying and waiting for what remained of it in her mouth to grow to its original length. The temple was filled with spectators, who remianed till a late hour to see miracle number two brought off.

The woman waited till a little past midnight, most of the time in a kneeling posture, but the tongue would not grow. The temple authorities advised her to return home, as they declared her not "good enough for miracles."

div.head: Zizinia Theatre.
div.p: A special performance of Cyrano de Bergerac will be given to-morrow evening in aid of the Société Internationale des Employés d'Alexandrie.

div.head: Austro-Hungarian Ball.
div.p: The ball of the Cairo Austro-Hungarian Benevolent Society, or der the patronage of Cpnnt K^brodski, will b9 given on the 23rd inst. at the Savoy Hotel.

div.head: Regimental Sports.
div.p: The regimental sports of the Royal InniskU-ling FaRiliers will be held on Satarday, 10th inst. The invitations previously issued hold good for this date.

div.head: Alexandria Blind School.
div.p: Mrs. Moss ai d Mrs. Carver have very kindly given the boys of the Blind School a treat for the New Year and have also contributed towards the funds of the institution.

div.head: Death in the Bath.
div.p: A native porter was yesterday taking a bath in his master's house in the Attarin quarter when he was suffocated inside the bath by the fumes of the charcoal.

div.head: Alhambra Theatre.
div.p: During the last few days of the French operetta company's stay, until the 11th inst., the prices of admission will be reduced to P.T. ^0 and P.T. 5, boxes being P.T. 60.

div.head: Walker and Meimarachi.
div.p: The subscription list for the new issue of shares opens to-morrow and closes on the 9th inst. Anplications must be addressed to the Anglo-Egyptian Bank.Limited.at Cairo or Alexandria. [Advt.]

div.head: Murder.
div.p: The Greek rayah who was stabbed with a knife by a waiter of Greek origin at Rarmoas on the 29th ult., succumbed to his injuries yesterday. The murderer, who confessed his crime, is in prisoD.

div.head: Cotton in Turkey.
div.p: The Sublime Ottoman Porte has decided to purchase a large quantity of Egyptian cotton Reed in order to distribute it among the farmers throughout the Empire so that the cotton m*y be improved.

div.head: Pleasure Cruises.
div.p: Among the liners dae at Alexandria this month on pleasure cruises are the S S. Orient, of the Orient-Pacific Line, which arrives on the 23rd inst for a four days' stay, and the Hamburg-America's S.S. Moltke, dae at Alexandria on the 27th inst.

div.head: Prince and Nazli's Statements.
div.p: The declaration of Prinoass Nazli as to the Egyptians being only babies politically still smonlders in the Columns of the vernacular Pres$>^'Al Express" condones her Highness's remark on the ground thit she ia not of Egyptian but of Turkish origin.

div.head: British Chamber of Commerce.
div.p: The annual general meeting pf members of the British Chamber of Commerce of Egypt will be held to-morrow (Wednesday) at. 4 p m., in Messrs. Carver Bros. and Company's office0,Old Boarse-street, Alexandria, to receive the committee's report and accounts for the year 19 >5, and to el set four me chars to the committee for 1906.

div.head: A Musical Event,
div.p: Signor Arrgo Serato's third concert is advertised to taka place at fhs Continental Hotel on Wednesday, 7th inst.., at 5 15 p.m., when he will be accompanied as nsnal by that gifted pianiste, Mme.Malatesta.The programme holds many items, including a sonata of Saint-Saens and a polonaise of Vieaxtempa, and Mme Malltesta will contribute as her solos a toccata by Chaminada and also one of Liszt's rhapsodies.

There are multitudes of genuine speoi m^n*> raoging in date oyer a very long period v -"there/are predyoastic seals in existence, though not of precisely this shape—and there is, of course, a busy manufactory of imitations. div.head: ALGECIRAS CONFERENCE. OPTIMISTIC OUTLOOK PREVALENT.
div.p: A very firm tone prevails owing to the important announcement of Count Cassini, the Russian delegate at the Algeoiras Conference, who has described his views as to the outcome of the Conference's proceedings as being more than optimistic.
The German official and semi-official press is also giving vent to satisfactory assurances of a pacific solution to the Morocco question.

div.head: DUCAL ENGAGEMENT.
div.p: The engagement is announced of the wealthiest heiress in Great Britain, Lady Mary Hamilton, daughter of the 12th Duke' of Hamilton and Brandon, to the Marquis of Graham, heir to the dukedom of Montrose .

div.head: THE UNIONIST SPLIT.
div.p: The Rt. Hod. Walter Long, who was pointed out as a possible leader to tha distracted Unionist Party, has declared formally that he has no intention whatsoever of taking the leadership.

div.head: THE TURNER TREASURE TROVE.
div.p: Extraordinary interest is being manifested in the wonderfol discovery of forgotten masterpieces of Tamer. Huge crowds flocked to see these pictures yesterday.

div.head: KHEDIVIAL LEVEE
div.p: The Khedive's Kourban-Beyram reception was largely attended.

A great number of ladies connected with the Corps Diplomatique and Cairo society were present at the reception held by H.H. the Khedivah and H H. the Khedivah- Mother at Abdeen Palace on Sauday afternoon. The reception took plaoe in one of the large drawing rooms of the Palace, the Khedivah antt Khedivah Mother occupying two large throne like chairs, and Mme De Martino acting as mistress of the ceremonies for the former, while Miss Home undertook the same duties for the latter. The European ladies were received at 3.30, and the ladies belonging to the Corps Diplomatique at 4.30; and nearly all the well-known members of Cairo society were present during these different hours. The distinguished hosts, who were beautifully dressed in European costume, received thpir guests with much graciousness, and chatted free'y with their friends, while tea and refreshments ware served. Prominent among those ladies belonging to the Corps Diplomatique were Mrs. Findlay, who represented Lady Cromer, the Marchioness Salvago-Raggi, Countess Serionne Baroness Ruoker Jenisch, Mrs. lddings, Mme and Mile Villebois. Mme and Mile de la Boulinire, and Mme Maskens.' Among those who attended the reception at the earlier hours were Mrs. and Mis Bullook, Mrs and Misses Coles, Mrs. R"*yle, Mrs. 8a*ow, Mme Fabrioius, Mme Haller, Mrs. Carton de Wiart, Mme Adolphe Cattaui, Mme J iseph Cattaui, Mme Snares, Mme Charles He Lesseps, Mrs. De.avoye, and Mrs. and Miss Reid.

div.head: THE DOMINO BALL
div.p: With regard to the much talked-of domino ball to be given by the pairo Comity des FStes on Friday, we hear whispers that the aforesaid committee will not insist toorigo rously on the oolonrs, pink and pnrple, of the dominoes worn. Only as a settled scheme of colour adds so much to the effectiveness of the ensemble it is hoped that all those who can manage to do so will appear in garments of either one pr other of these colours.

So much gratis amusement is provided in Cairo for the visitors and society in general, that it is hoped that society this winter will endeavour to appreciate the efforts of the Comity des Fdtes, and give its support to this ball on Friday, which is the only one which makes any call upon its purse-strings. People are not above reasoning that as they can enjoy five dances on five nights in the week for nothing why should they pay for the sixth on the sixth night, and quite ignoring the fact that if they have taken advantage of five gratuitous evenings' amusement they surely can afford to give their one donation to a society whoso one aim is to add to the attractiveness of Cairn.

div.head: STEAMER MOVEMENTS
div.p: The Moss liner Menes sailed henre yesterday morning-for Liverpool via Malta with passengers, mails and general cargo including 4,623 bales cotton.
The Moss liner Menepthah arrived at Liverpool yesterday.

div.head: PORT SUDAN - AN INTERESTING VISIT. LORD CROMER VISITS CONTRACTOR'S
div.p: On the occasion of the opening* of the Nile- Red Sea Railway, Lord Cromer paid a visit to the works at Port Sudan of Messrs. Ben- cini and Quistes, harbour contractors^ and constructors of the port of Port Sudan. This firm has actually done part of the harbour of Alexandria. His lordship, accompanied by H. E. the Sirdar and all the staff, stepped out of the Palace car, for which a special line was laid leading to Messrs. Benoini and Qaistas' woiks, and was received by Mr. A. Bencini, con tractor,and Mr. A. G.Cookilani,who manages the administrative part of the conoern. His lordship was conducted to a special marquee erected for the purpose in which Mr. Benoini gave the following speech;—
E altissimo ouore rivolgere la parola a Vostra Signoria e per averla oonoessa la mia Impresa ve n' rioonoscente.
L'esservi benignato di visitare questo modes- to Cantiere di lavoro dimostra una volta di pih che dove mroate il vostro passo sapete imprimere nuove orme di Civilta e di progresso.
Cio' mi reude ardito di chiedervi l'altro ono- re di voler inaugurare la nostra modesta officina e qae:ito sark auspice della buona nuscita del nostro lavoro.
Gradire l'espressione del profondo rispetto che io vi presento a nome dell'Impresa e di quanti ItUiani qui si trovano e che mi hanno oonces^o l'alto onore di ossequirvi a loro nome.

His lordship passed through a magnificent triumphal arch representing land and sea works to be carried out by the company. The pathway from the triumphal aroh to the splendid workshops of Benoini and Quotas was lined by European and native workmen, who cheered Lord Oomer and the Sirdar three times. The latter was accompanied by Lady Wingate, who also went over the works accompanied by Mrs. A. Benoini. Among others present was Sir Vincent Corbett. Lord Cromer was shown the plans of the harbour and seemed most satisfied with everything, as was justified by the reply which he made to Mr. Benoini's words of welcome. Lord Cromer remained about three- quarters of au hour in the works.

div.head: LORD CROMER'S RETURN
div.p: Lord Cromer arrived at Cairo from Luxor at 7.30 this moramg, after a good journey, looking in the best of health.

div.head: THE PRESS REPRESENTATIVES
div.p: Owen Bey, with Chawarbi Pacha, Ahmed Pacha Yehia, and several members of the Press, arrived at Cairo at 8.3 > a.m. to-day. H. E the Governor-General ef the Sudan has sent a gracious reply to a telegram sent by the Press representatives who attended the Sudan oeremouies, expressing their thanks for the kindness and attention shown them during their stay in the Sudan.

div.head: THE PILGRIMAGE
div.p: A telegram from Mina, from the Quarantine Board's delegate at the Hedjac, states that the fetes in conneotiou with the pilgrimage are over. The deaths at Ararat have amounted to 12 and at Mouna to 20, all from ordinary causes. The number of pilgrims at Mecca is 195,000 and the health of all is reported to be perfect.

div.head: EGYPT AND HUNGARY
div.p: The Hungarian Commer ial Bank at Budapest has taken the first practical step in the discussion of the furtherance of Austro-Hungarian trade by the banks, in founding the Hungarian Oversea Commercial Company, which will have for its principal objeot the export of Hungarian agricultural and also industrial products to Abyssinia, Egypt, the Sudan, Northern Africa, and the Near East in general. The relatively modest share capital of the new concern will be gradually increased with the development of its operations. The Hungarian Commercial Bank, moreover, ex pects a State subsidy to be granted to it* venture.

div.head: NOTES FROM MENA
div.p: The season at the Pyramids has starred rather early this year. All Cairo seemed to be out there on Sunday, and as Mena House Hotel is more than Tall* there was a very fashionable gathering on the large and beauti ful terrace, such as has never been seen there before. The races this afternoon will no doubt brirg out a orowd again. The entries for the different events efire very numerous, andi everybody is looking forward to the meeting with keen interest. Evidently, the management of Mena House Hotel is not behindhand in seeing that its visitors are well entertained. A special concert has been arranged for Thursday night on the terrtfoa, and as it wi b^ full uom many people will no doubt take a vantsge to go out and see the Sphinx a» the Pyramids by moonlight, and spend a fe* hours at ahe hotel. Special dinners will be prepared for this night.

div.head: LA DOGARESSA HISSED
div.p: There was an extraordinary scene on Saturday night at the Khedivial Opera House at Cairo, when Mr. Sinadino's opera La Dogaressa was for the third time given before the samp series of abonn. The theatre rose as ont man And hissed with fury. The final act was given to an empty house.

To THE EDITOR OF THE EGYPTIAN GAZETTE. Sir, - The outspoken letter, which you published to-day OQ the forthcoming Alexandria Municipal Elections, represents the general feeling of the respectable portion of the com munity. In fact, nobody with any self-respect ought to trouble to vote, for the whole thing is an utter farce, and I cannot imagine how any honest man«an desire to ^e elected to such an institution except for purely personal motives. Of oonrse these motives may be innoxious. For exMnple some valgarian may de ire to ffe: himself as a candidate becaupe he is stupid enough to believe that the title of Municipal Councillor will help to give him some position over and above that conferred on him by hisjvealth. Such types of persons are at any rate better than the sordid self seeker, who only wants a seaton the Municipal Council in order to make money by using the Municipality as a tool for his nefarious s jhemes. Ypur correspondent complains that among the candidates for the coming elections, "Auonn personnage adrieux n'est enoorn mis ur lea rangs etoelase oon^fit: il est difficile, poor ne pas dire impossible, à un bon oandidat de se faire dlire, sans s'abaisjer à des proed 141 pen recoramamlableR." Bnt'finreiy this is not a ground for complaint.

div.head: EGYPTS BLIND - AN EXCELLENT INSTITUTION
div.p: a few minutes only from the railway station there, has at present 27 resident-pupils, with room for others up to a limit of 35 altogether, besides a comparatively fewer number of day-pupils ; satisfactory arrangements are, however, now concluded for day-pupils being trained in greater numbers at the workshop for the blind which is being opened at Boulac, and which should be ready for working 6ar)y this month (Febxoaty). A teaoher from England has been specially engaged to superintend this branch, which principally comprises basket-making and chait-making, to to time, as the number of pupils is increased. Many of the popils are already adept at re-caning of ohatrs, for which there is a constant and considerable demand. Specimens of work are on sale at the dep6t (at 8, Chareh Bab ii-Hadid), near the Cairo railway station, where orders for work oan aUo be given. At the same time, the institution pro- duces literature for the blind in the form of Arabio Braille, and not only supplies books required by the pupils in their sohool-work, bat fills the literary needs of others who are blind throughout Egypt and in adjacent countries where Arabio is spoken. The kind interest in the institution displayed by H.H. the Khedive, and by the Earl of Cromer, has been of the greatest vriue, and the Egyptian Government, also, has granted it an annual subsidy; it is therefore an easier task for the wide circle of the public, both resident and visitors, whose sympathies o*n picture what life would be to themselves individually if entirely deprived of eyesight, to share in helping this work for the blind, by contributing to it in accordance with their several abilities The need of help in this direction is really almost more pressing in Egypt than elsewhere, because of the hopelessness of ; vett heir infirmity 'and the unutterably debased condition into which so many of this poo^ and unfortunate class sink. All contributions to the income of the institution are applied exclusively for the benefit of the blind papils, and ths whole work of administration by the committ3e is done gratuitously, and, in addition, the late founder's family having generously secured the premises at Zeitoun to the institution at an entirely nominal rental, every increase of the fands therefore, beyond the sum of £1500, which is required annually, oan be devoted to at once benefiting an increased number of blind pupils ; all ot whom, as soon as they are sufficiently trained to produce work of saleable value, receive dae renamertio Subscriptions and donations of any sum will be welcomed and may be paid, in Cairo, to the hon. treasurer, Mr. E. A. Harrison, at Messrs. Tbos. Cook & Son's offi e ; or to the hon. secretary, Dr. Kenneth Scott, 31, Chareh el- Falaki; or they may be placed directly to the account of the institution, at the National Bauk of Egypt. All further particulars may be obtained by inquiry from the hon. secretary, as above ; of om the principal, at the Institution for the Blind, Zeitoun. The regular viritiug day to see the school is on Thursday afternoon.

div.head: PERSONAL AND SOCIAL
div.p: Lord Morley has arrived in Egypt and is staying at the Savoy Hotel, prior to vuiting Luxor and Assouan. Lord Morl«»y was bom in 1877 and sncceeded his father, the 3rd Earl of Morley, in February of last year. His father was for many years Chairman of Committees and Deputy Speaker of the Houpe of Commons and, like him. the present Earl is a Liberal Unionist. He is one of the largest and most popular landowners in Devonshire, possessing some 8 000 acres, and at his home at Saltram there is a fine collection of Joshua Reynold's pictures He is unmarried and his heir is the Hon. Montagu Brownlow Parker, his younger brother. 1868. He joined the Royal Navy in 1840 at the age of nineteen, but in 1851 he resigned his commission to serve under his. unolein Sarawak. He was prominent in helping to restore the ooanjbry to order and put down piracy and head-hu'ntiog. He ra!ei over a population of 500,000 souls and his country has an extent of 40,000 square miles. div.head:
THE UNIONIST PARTY
BALFOUR v. CHAMBERLAIN. QUESTION OF THE LEADERSHIP.

div.p: The Unionist party will meet next week in order to consider the position.

The 'Time says that Mr. Chamberlain desires to make the tariff reform paramount in thepolioy of the Unionists. It is understood l that Mr. Balfour will not assent, considering it inexpedient in view of the result of the elections. If Mr. Balfour adheres to this standpoint, Mr. Chamberlain, who is personally unwilling to take the leadership, will propose a third person, probably Mr, Long, to lead the party. Mr. Balfour deolines to acquiesce an 1 considers it highly inadvisable to exclude from the party the Unionists who do not oonour in the Chamberlaini te fiscal policy.

The Unionist newspapers are divided on the leadership of the party. The "Standard," the "Morning Post," and the "Globe'^are strongly Chamberlainite. Others uphold Mr. Balfour, The "Times" strongly deprecates any widening of the cleavage and considers^that in the present situation the Unionist party has no nee 1 to formulate a vary definite policy. It is noteworthy that the personal relations between Mr. Balfour and Mr. Chamberlain are most friendly. (Reuter)

div.head: THE NILE RED SEA RAILWAY - HOME PRESS ON THE OPENING
div.p: Below we give a few extracts from the Eure J?ean Press comments on the inauguration c t the Berber-Suakin Railway :—
V; "STANDARD."

The new railway from the dile to the R'd 8ea, which was formally opened on Siturdiy by Lord Cromer, may be added to the list if signal benefits which the laud of Egypt owes to the influence, *he incitement, and, we need no* be ashamed to add, the interference of English men. But for the bsnefioent part that Englanl has played in Egyptian affairs, it is more th* n probable that the Sudan, to this day, would b sank in barbarism and anarohy, unless, indeed, some fanatical conqneror from the Upper Ni e had not succeeded in overrunning Lower Egypt with his hordes. A Sudan under an orderly Government, and likely to become a prosperous province of the Khedive's dominions, would have been an unattainable ideal. Thanks to the military achievements of Lord Kitchene*, and to the able and vigorous administration of Lord Cromer, whose share in the work the viotor of Omdurman was always eager to acknowledge, the Sadan was recovered, and the new railway will do more than anything to develop its resefaroes and ensnre the maintenance of the Khedive's authority

Nothing bat a complete reversal aud abandonment of the wise and benevolent polioy which has been followed in Egypt for the past twenty years and more could prevent the fulfilment of Lord Cromer's most sanguine expectation* ; and, indeed, so mnch has a'ready been accomplished that it wonld pnzzle the most malignant and mischievous genius ever entrusted with the control of public affairs to reverse the engines of progress. The machinery of good government and far-sighted administration is in working order both in Egypt and the Sudan, and it is hard to oonoeive the growth of any sinister force powerful enough to oheok it. At the same time, we cannot help noticing with Atisfaotion that Lord Cromer disclaims any intention of relinquishing the task which he has disoharged so well as long as health and strength are left to him. His presenoe in Egypt is, indeed, the surest guarantee that the interests of England, will not suffer through any change in the direotion of the. affairs of this nation ; and that the develop ment of the resouroes of the Sudan, and the steady reclamation of its people, will proceed without interruption.
"DAILY TELEGRAPH." ^

It is only the unimaginative who say that the Age of Romance ha > gone by for ever. Marvels are being accomplished in these falsely-styled prosaic days, which equal anti surpass the most astonishing aohievements of bygone ages. For example, we record to-day the opening by Lord Cromer of the new railway from the Red Sea to Berber, which deserves a place among the modern wonders of the world. Not, of coarse, because of the engineering difficulties, met and overcome, that make some railways famoas. The laying of a line across three hundred miles of sand doe3 not exoite the wonder* that is aroused by the piercing of the Simplon* Tunnel, by the spanning of the Victoria Falls, by the asoent of a Swiss mountain, or by colossal achievements like the Trans-Siberian Railway, which flows eastward for thousands of miles in unbroken sequence. There have, of coarse,been special difficulties in the Sadan, difficulties of transport, of panoity of labour, of overpowering heat, of sudden washouts sweeping away in a few hours the work of weeks. For surmounting these in a short fourteen months Lieutenant Colonel Macauley is justly entitled to the glowing praise which Lord Cromer lavished upon him on Saturday, and, like all else in Egypt and the Sudan, the thing has been done not only efficiently, but oheaply. It has cost less than a million and a half pounds Egyptian, for money is not. wasted in the Nile Valley, where the Administration outs its coat according to its oloth, orrefases permission to out at all. But the real miraole of the new railway is not physical, but moral. Twenty-one years ago, almo*t to the very day, General Gordon died the death of a hero on the steps of the Residency at Khartonm. The work of civilisation seemed to be blotted out absolutely. commerce. Port Sadan, the new port, forty-five miles north of Saakiu,whioh has been judged to offer batter harbourage than the p'aoe which it is certain to supersede, will know no diserimir. ating tariff'. All traders will fare alike; tin prizes will fall to the cleveresf. This' is the best answer which Great Britain conld make to those belated rritioa— now a rapidly dwindling band - who say that she has only s iught her owu selfish ends in the Sudan, and deny her title deeds. The policy ofthe open door involves, however, one danger to the niwly found prosperity of the Sudan, on which Lord Cromer spoke very wisely and to the point. O^en doors attract undesirable goods and undesirable persons, who enter with the honest trader. It will be the duty of the Administration to repress all such by means of rigorous laws, for, tractable as the natives now are—even the members of the old ruling tribe—there is always the possibility of a recrudescence of fanaticism. But on this head Sir Reginald Wingate may be trusted to take adequate precautions, and the advantages of the open door will, it is thought, greatly exceed its drawbacks. We hope that the expectations founded on the completion of this new railway will be triumphantly realised, and that Lord Cromer and his eager and oapable lieutenants may see the Sudan stride rapidly forward along the path of progress.
"TRIBUNE."

We are glad to see that Lord Cromer did not emphasize the railway's strategical valne. It is not a military, bat a genuine oommeroial railway, designed to open and develop country which hitherto lay stagnant and isolated. Even a railway cannot fertilize a desert, and it will do little for the oonntry between Berber and the coast Bat it taps the fertile Nile valley and brings Khartonm within easy reach of the sea. Its building is an interesting commentary on the Cape-to Cairo scheme .of the late Mr. Rhodes. What Africa needs is not a long backbone railway from north to sonth, bat a series of short lines which will bring the pro dnoe of the interior swiftly down to the ee« Nothing that Khartonm prodaces will stand the cost of the long journey to Alexandria. A short line to the nearest available seaport may at last open up an economic future for the Sadan.

div.head: REDEMPTIVE FORCES IN EGYPT
div.p: The first great work of redemption recorded in Scripture took place in this remarkable valley of the Nile 3,500 years ago. Then Jehovah called the chosen people ont of Egypt in order that they might develop a religion of apin^tial realities in an atmosphere of relative freedom from pagan domination. The story ' j* familiar to every stndent of Seriptare, foil of the pathos of Israel's unbeliet and disobe- dieice. Now, after nineteen Christian centuries the followers of Christ are striving to give the knowledge of the trne God as it is revealed in Jesus Christ to the people of this land.

In a former letter reference was made to the denominational adjustment according to which the United Presbyterians were given the land of Egypt as their field among the countries about the Mediterranean. They have a record of most faithful, wise and efficient service upon which God's blessing has mani: festly rested. Not only have they spread their activities over the Delta* but also into Upper Egypt and on into the oudau. Their great mission house in Cairo bespeaks large interests in Egypt, as well as permanency ot occupation. Their fine college at Assiout, with more than 600 young men and boys in attendance, reminds the visitor of Robert College in Constantinople and the Syrian Protestant College in Beyrout. Here also, as in Turkey, ja and Palestine, the Christian schools are every hand and are crowded to their ntmost capacity.

It was with great pleasure that we accepted an invitation to give some time to Egypt, as it was directly in the way of our journey to Ind;8. Some two weeks have given us the opportunity of seeing the work and meeting the workers, We landed at Alexandria, where Rev. William L. McLenahan is the leader of the groop labouring in that thriving, modern city. There were meetings for the workers and a service for the native congregation. It was an agreeable surprise to find a handsome stone church occupied by these native congregations. The building was erected for them by the First United Presbyterian Churoh of Allegheny, and its splendid appearance adds very materially to the general impression throughout the city regarding the importance of the Christian enterprise.

Cairo is a great oity. In every part of Egypt the marvellous progress made since the British occupation is constantly in evidence along commercial and political lines, and this is distinctively true in Cairo. It is unfortunate that the same thing oanuot be said regarding religious oonditipns. fn the one respect of religious liberty there is improvement, but in general the British Government favours the jMbbamedani, and not the Christians, in all its rules concerning those features of the public welfare which involve religious preferences. For instance, Eoglish teachers are brought here for the Government sohools, but the Mohamedan Sabbath is observed ; that is Friday, and the schools are all continued on Sunday, the teachers being unable to observe the Christian Sabbath. The Moh»medans laugh at this, and say the British are afraid to interfere with their religious affairs. The Christians do not ask that Mohamedans be debarred from their fullest liberty on Friday, but feel keenly their hardship in not having equal liberty on the Sabbath. The result is that these young teachers have no Sabbath, and many are drifting away from their anchorage in the Christian faith.

jrfere are three veterans at Cairo: Drs. f Watson, Ewing and Harvey, all labouring here for more than forty years. With them Dr. Murch. and several noble womeo, record three decades of faithful service. The schools are crowded, and the preaching services are maintained at six different centres. Meetings of various kinds are held here, the services for the people being crowded, though the large auditorium in theMissionBuilding accommodates nearly a thousand people. A most interesting meeting held regularly each week in Cairo is for Mohamedan =», and is led by a converted Mohamedan, who is one of the finest Arabic scholars in the oity. Evidences multiply to strengthen faith in God's blessing upon the efforts to reach the Moslem people.

A four days' conference for all the workers in Egypt was ananged for November 7-10, at Assiout, the seat cf the College, so well ad ministered by President J. R. Alexander. It was a notable gathering (f missionaries and native pastors from the Delta to the Sadan. There had been many weeks of faithful prayer lor a great Hewing upon this gathering, and the answer was graciously given. AIL the services were in Arabic for the sake of .the pastors, the five addresses of the writer being interpreted by a most efficient master of both
work, and are trained to meet a demand for th:, commodity by tourists who orowd Luxor during the season. * 4

Mention of the tourist season recalls the sad fact that many nominal Christians come tc Egypt and oonduot themselves in such a w*y as to hurt the oause of Christ. An aggravated instance is the example of the Episcopal clergyman at Luxor, who is there for the season at a leading hotel. Having read the service Sabbath mornings, he is the organizer of the afcernoon excursions on that day and the leader of the dances and various entertainments arranged daring the week. Is it strange that many Mohamedans are very slow to believe that Christians aTe truly religious t '

Progress is being steadily noted all along the line, however, in spite of an empty nominal Christianity. The Chnrob of England has sent many faithful representatives to this and other countries about the Mediterranean Set. A new day has dawned upon Egypt, and its blessed light is that which shines from the cross of Christ. Africa is stretohing forth her hands unto God. The God of nations snddealy opened the way, and he will continue to lead his people as they strive to be faithful witnesses for the world's only Saviour. There is an increasing expectation from Goi for Egypt in the prayers of believers, and it will not be long before the Pentecostal blesjings will oome. (From ''The Herald and Presbyter.")

div.head: ROCKEFELLER AFTER EGYPTIAN RELICS
div.p: The authorities at the British Museum are about to make an C3pecLltfibrt to interest the Government in the purchase by the public ot valuable Egyptian relios.This action, it appears, is doe to the information that John D. Rockefeller has commissioned a well-known American Egyptologist to survey the whole of the Sudab, and has placed praotioally unlimited finances at his disposal to pick up anything he oan that is worth buying. One of the most famous Egyptologists in Eugland, in the oourse of an interview, said he sincerely trusted the Government would take some deoided steps to deal with the habit ot American millionaires of presenting their native towns with Egyptian antiquities, for, with their wealth, the Americans seemed able at present to snap up every thing that is preoions in connection with Egypt's past.

div.head: SPORT AND PLAY
div.p: The B. R. C. (Alexandria) were the winners of the match which was shot off yesterday morning between their first team and a team from the 1st Royal Dublin Fusiliers. The shooting was favoured with fine weather, bat the glare was very strong and the fresh wind at times difficult to gauge. Mr. Lias' shooting merits special notice. Scores B. R. C. (ALEXANDRIA).

div.head: SHOULD CLERGYMEN MARRY?
div.p: T! e * Nineteenth Century" for February co .tains an interesting article by Bishop Well- don on "The Children of the Clergy." In any just estimot* of the advantages attaching to a married or a celibate clergy (says the writer) it is neoessary to take account of the part which the children of the olergy have played in the national life. It has sometimes seemed to me, therefore, that such stndents of sociology as are interested in the question of a celibate or a marripd olergy might be helped to a just conclusion by ascertaining the sum total, so to call it, of the contribution, whether intePeotual or ethical or spiritual, which the clergy of Great Britain have, since the Reformation, made in the persons of their children, to the treasury of the national life.

That splendid literary monr ment the "Dictionary of National Biography" has for the first time in Eoglish history rendered snch an estimate possible. It has been my self-imposed task to examine the parentage of every person whose name ooonrs in the sixty-three original dictionary ; and if I oonfine myself to the oen- tories succeeding the Reformation, daring which the Protestant olergy have been allowed to marry, it is safe to assert not only that the olerioal profession has sent out an immense number of children who, acoording to the language of the Bidding Prayer in the ancient universities, have "served God both in Chnroh and State" with success and distinction, bat that no other profession has sent ont so many children equally successful and equally distinguished

To begin with the mere enumeration of names : Although there are, in the "Dictionary of National Biography," a good many names of sons or daughters of the clergy which can scarcely be said to merit national recognition, yet the name* which I marked as worthy of remembranoe for some service performed in religion, -or politics, or liteiatore, or science, or art, or commerce, or philanthropy, or warfare, or some other aspect of the various life of the nation, amouuted to 1270. Large as this numfyar is it consists solely of men and women whope fathers were clergymen or ministers of religion; it takes no account of the many more who were grandchildren either on their fathers' or their mothers' side, or still more remote descendants and relations, of clergymen or ministers. Yet even so it allows something no*: far short of f >nr hundred names for eaoh century since the Reformation.distinguished
legal and medioal professions put together,, whether since the Reformation or before it.

The superiority has been one not of numbers only brit of degree. From olerioaknomes have -prnng sons more distingniphed^apd a larger number of more distinguished sons, than from the hemes of any seonlar profession.

It is not perhaps wonderful (says Bishop Wildon, in concluding his artiole in the "Nineteenth Century") that the olerioal homes of Great Britain thonld have proved to be a soil prolific of learning and virtae and patriotic devotion. For nowhere is domestic life more favourable to the cultivation of high moral qualities. The olergy are a body ot citizens
whose calling in life tends, or ought to tend, to \ V « , .. a u -D

raise them a little abeve the common level of Mrs. I. F. Mims and suite, Savannah; Rev Dr humanity. They are the expositors of lofty Colin and Mrs. Campbell, Scotland; Mr. and motives and duties ; they onght, therefore, to Mrs. J. Dickson, Edinburgh, Mr. C. Prag, feel them and practise them. Tbejr have reoeiv-j Dresden ; Mr. Hans Trier, London

div.head: TO OUR VISITORS
div.p: The lias much pleasure in presenting to its subscribers the accompanying description of some of the many interesting routes by which they may travel homewards. Great care has been taken to arrange them as accurately and concisely as possible, and it will be found that none of them tare fraught with difficulty. In choosing the route home there are several things to be considered. To begin with there is the differehce in climate between Egypt and the various points at which yoa may arrive in Europe.
Many people leave Egypt far too eaiH' in tlie year, for as a rule the weather in .Jpril and May is perfect. The wannest place to go to on leaving Egypt is Sicily.

Some will want to take into consideration the number of days to be spent at sea,-and we therefore subjoin a list showing tlie time occupied on each of the various routes between Egypt and the Continent of Europe.
Port Said or Alexandria to Brindisi 3 days | to Egypt.
Alexandria to Messina 3
Port Said or Alexandria to Marseilles 5 Alexandria toVenice and Trieste... 4
Alexandria to Naples 3
Port Said to Genoa 5
Port Said to Naples 4
Alexandria to Constantinople ... 4
Alexandria to Piraeus 2
Port Said to Gibraltar 7
As regards the train journeys from Cairo, the shortest is that to Alexandria, without change (3 hours). That to Port Said, can now be made without change in \\ hours.

The least expensive way to England is by the Moss, Papayanni, Prince, and Westcott lines of steamers from Alexandria to Liverpool. The German Levant line has also good steamers from Alexandria to Hamburg.

The most expensive but quickest through mails from the great liner arrived from Continental routes are by P. & 0. Brindisi Bombay. express from Port Said, and the Austrian These small but comfortable ships have Lloyd Prieste-Vienna express from Alexandria, enormously powerful engines, and attain a As regards heavy luggage, it must be boiVie very high rate of speed. They are called the in mind that very little luggage is allowed "Ferry boats," having been specially built tQ free on the railways of Europe, hut there arc carry the British mail from Port Said to several good and responsible forwarding agents Brindisi. If you are going straight through to in Egypt who undertake at a fixed charge to England yo will find the train waiting at deliver packages to any address in Europe. Brindisi which will take you to Calais without The quickest manner of getting to Europe changing. It has complete arrangements for from Port Said js undoubtedly by the fast sleeping and eating on hoard, and you should Mail Steamers "Osiris" and "Isis" to Brindisi, arrive in London on the fifth day from leaving One of these leaves Port Said every week, 4as Port Said, soon as possible after receiving the Indian

div.head: SICILY
div.p: The direct route to Sicily is by the Florio- Rnbattino Co.'s steamers which leave Alexandria weekly for MESSINA, where one takes train to TAORMINA, one of the most charming and popular places on the island. Giardini is 'he station at which to alight, and the drive up to Taormina is most delightful, occupying about one hour. In and around the town is much to interest the visitor. The theatre is of Greek origin, but restored under the Romans. CATANIA is the starting place for the ascent of Etna and here also is a fine Cathedral. The Greek, Roman, and Saracenic remains that are found all over the island, are an endless sources of pleasure. SYRACUSE has an interesting history, having been a Greek city, whicn was designed by Demosthenes in B.C. 413, and taken by the Romans in B.C. 212, when Archimedes was slain—his tomb is to be seen. The cathedral was once an ancient pagan temple. PALERMO, with abo"t 300,000 inhabitants, is the capital of the Island, and enjoys a delightful climate. Much of interest is to be found in this fine city. The Palazzo Reale is of Saracenic origin and close to it the church of S. (li wannia degli Eremiti with its picturesque cloisters. The Cathedral, Museum, Botanic Gardens, Villa Giulia and Royal Park are also worth a visit.

div.head: CENTRAL ITALY
div.p: Y'The fine steamers of the North German Lloyd leave Alexandria every Wednesday during the season for Naples, the voyage being only 3 days. NAPLES is also reached in 10 hours from Palennoby the Florio-R"battino Co.'s steamers, which leave daily. One cannot approach Naples or leave it without wishing to explore some of its islands, besides the lovely places on its bay—Castellamare and Sorrento: The small steamer that takes you to Sorrento [you can drive too] will take you on to Caprir From Naples to ROME is a train journey of but five hours. All who can will devote at least one week to visiting the many historical and interesting portions of the Eternal City, whose charms and beauties are too well-known to need comment here. Leaving the Eternal City with much regret, a railway journey of five nours brings you to FLORENCE, where another week can well be spent .admiring tho City oj Flowers and its surrounding country. In Florence itself the churches and galleries^ are of absorbing interest, whilst the local promenades and excursions should not be omitted. The Cascine is the most attractive and fashionable promenade in Florence, whilst the Viale dei Colli, one • of the finest walks in Europe, opened 35 years ago, goes winding up through the hills a distance of four miles. The most delightful excursion outside Florence is that to Vallom- brosa, with its Monastery 3,300 feet above the sea level. This is made first by ordinary train from Florence to St. Ellero, thence bv cogwheel railway to Saltino. The ascent through groves of oaks takes an hour, and most striking panoramas are unfolded to view. PISA is easily reached from Florence in about 2 hours ; here there'is a fine Cathedral and the Leaning Tower. A stay of at least one night should if possible be made, in order to enjoy the view from the Campanile at sunset. VIAREGGIO. One of the most delightful places on the Italian Riviera near Pisa and on the main line from Rome to Genoa. It is a very convenient half-way house between Egypt and England, and where living is reasonable and the air and surroundings exceptionally good.

div.head: NORTHERN ITALY
div.p: GFNOA (La Superba).—The most picturevsque and interesting city- in .Italy, with the record of having one of the lowest death averages of European cities and a phenomenally equable temperature—warm in winter and deliciously cool breezes from the surrounding mountains and the Mediterranean in summer. Tlie patriarchal home of Italy's most an- eient nobility, whose palaces, gardens, and famous collections, of statuary, frescoes, and paintings, are a constant delight to thousands of travellers who annually sojourn in Genoa. Then there are the superbly decorated medieval churches containing exquisite marble columns and historical paintings, and the incomparable Campo Santo filled with its wonderful tombs. From Genoa to Milan is a rnatler of only three hours by rail. MILAN is a good centre lor Northern Italy before making the to* r of the Lakes. The Cathedral is the principal attraction,- with its beautiful windows illustrating the History of the Bible. The public gardens and the monu mental cemetery are also worth a visit. - Between Bologna and Milan and only an hour and-a-half from Milan is SALSOMAG- GIORE, a renowned health resort on account of its thermal springs, change trains at Borgo San Dovino and in half-an hour you arc at Salsomaggiore.

div.head: THE ITALIAN LAKES
div.p: VENICE is a 5 hours journey by rail from Milan, and one of the most delightful places imaginable to pass a quiet stay. The total absence of vehicular traffic strikes one as very strange ; no horse, cart, carriage or bicycle is to be seen, and ve* there is the sound' of life at every turn. The approach to Venice from the Adriatic is unlike that of any other seaport. The town seems to be gradually, like Aphrodite, horn of the sea, no hills behind, no stretches of rock, but first the tons of Campaniles appear above the horizon, tnen slowly the whole glittering town rises like a fairy mirage out of the calm lagoon. Going northwards from Milan you make the tour of the beautiful Italian lakes. COMO, the birthplace of the younger Pliny; is reached in one-and-a-quarter hours by train by way of Monza : .Boats leave Como frequently for the other towns on the lake, which is very beautiful, and the scenery on either side going up the lake is most enchanting. CERNOBBIO is a charming spot; then come Tremezzo, Cadenabbia, and Menaggio with the prettily-situated town of Bellaggio opposite. The walk from Tremezzo along the snore of the lake to Menaggio is most enjoyable. A steam tram runs from Menaggio to Porlezza on Lake Lugano irt three-quarters of an hour, then steamer to Lugano in two-and- three-quarter hours.

div.head: SWITZERLAND
div.p: Switzerland, the heart of Europe, has been described as "A cluster of delights and grandeurs." LUGANO is some 20 miles from Como and reached by train in one-and-affialf hours. It bos a populatien of 10,000 people aud is charmingly situated on the Lake of Lugano, amidst lovely Italian scenery. Arcnd it rise M. San Salvatore, M. de Caprinoand M. Generoso. LOCARNO may be reached by rail'from Bellinzona in forty minntes. This pretty town, situated at the top of Lake Maggiore, has a mild climate, and is an excellent winter resort. The'church Madonpa delSasso, situated above the town,is worth a visit, as it contains interesting paintings, "Entombment," by Ciseri, and "The Flight into Egypt,'' by Bramantion. 'LUCERNE.—A striking picture on the Lake of Lucerne facing the Iligi and Pilatus and the snow-clad Alps. In and around the town the walks are charming, and the excursions to be made from Lucerne by boat, rail, etc., are very numerous. The Like of Lucerne abounds in delightful excursions, those to the Bigi, Pilatus, Burgen stock and Sonnenberq needing a special visit eAch. Other excursions on the lake can be made by steamer, and the ever-changing scenery on the trip from Lucerne to Fluelen is a source of delight to the lover of nature: BRUNNEN, charmingly situated on the most beautiful part of the Lake of Lucerne, commands magnificent views of lake and mountain scenery. Along the Lake of Uri from \Brunnen to Fluelen runs the famous Axentrasse. A delightful excursion from Lucerne is that to ENGELBERG. Take boat to Stansstad* and from Stansstad it is about 1 hour and 40 min. by Electric Railway, with delightful scenery en route. The ascent of Titlis, is ru'tu tne utmost demands of modern science, and furnish made from here, and tlie panoramic view of SrSwBtoent°e8Sary for HydropfttLic> Mechanical, and Kiec- the Alps is grand; extending from Monte

div.head: GREECE AND IONIAN ISLES
div.p: Many people visit Greece after wintering in Egypt, as it is so easily reached from Alexandria ; the climate in April is charming. The best steamers are those of tfieJUiedivial Mail Co. and the Russian Steam Navigation Co. If possible tourists should/arrange to be in Athens for the Orthodox Easter .in order to witness the Good Friday and Easter Eve ceremonies, ^afid to be presen' at the dancing on the Easter Tuesday lestival held at Megara for which a special train is run from Athens. It is worth while to spend a few davs in CORFU on account of the beauty of the scenery. There is also good snipe and quail shooting to be had.
